instructions.instruction: Use Given/When/Then format for scenario-driven acceptance criteria where user interactions follow a specific sequence
instructions.original_snippets: Given/When/Then Format Use when acceptance criteria describe user interactions or workflows that follow a specific sequence... suitable for scenarios like login flows, checkout processes, or multi-step forms
instructions.relevant_when: Writing acceptance criteria for workflows with sequential user interactions like login, checkout, or multi-step processes

instructions.instruction: Use rule-oriented format for independent, stateless requirements that can be validated independently
instructions.original_snippets: Rule-Oriented Format Use when acceptance criteria describe independent requirements, business rules, or constraints that don't require a specific user journey... suitable for form validation, API responses, or UI behavior requirements
instructions.relevant_when: Writing acceptance criteria for independent requirements like form validation, API specifications, or UI constraints

instructions.instruction: Include both positive (happy path) and negative (failure/edge) scenarios in acceptance criteria
instructions.original_snippets: Anti-Pattern: Skipping negative scenarios... Add both positive (happy path) and negative (failure paths, edge cases) scenarios
instructions.relevant_when: Writing comprehensive acceptance criteria for any user story or feature

instructions.instruction: Make acceptance criteria measurable with specific numbers, timeframes, or observable outcomes instead of vague qualitative terms
instructions.original_snippets: Anti-Pattern: Vague, unmeasurable criteria... Bad: 'System should be fast'... Good: 'Page loads in <= 2 seconds'
instructions.relevant_when: Writing acceptance criteria that involve performance, quantities, or quality requirements

instructions.instruction: Focus on user outcomes and business value, not implementation details
instructions.original_snippets: Anti-Pattern: Implementation-focused criteria... Avoid describing HOW the system works internally. Focus on WHAT the user experiences... Anti-Pattern: Coupling multiple behaviors... Split complex criteria into independent, testable units
instructions.relevant_when: Writing acceptance criteria for any feature or user story

instructions.instruction: Validate acceptance criteria using INVEST criteria (Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, Testable)
instructions.original_snippets: ## INVEST Quality Checklist... Independent: No unrelated blockers or dependencies... Negotiable: Implementation details can be decided during development... Valuable: Provides clear user or business value... Estimable: Clear enough for development team to size... Small: Can be completed within a single iteration... Testable: Has objective, binary pass/fail criteria
instructions.relevant_when: Reviewing and validating user stories and their acceptance criteria

instructions.instruction: Include explicit scope boundaries with 'Out of Scope' sections to prevent scope creep
instructions.original_snippets: ## Out of Scope - Integration with third-party payment processors - Advanced fraud detection algorithms - Mobile app implementation
instructions.relevant_when: Writing comprehensive acceptance criteria for features with potential scope ambiguity

instructions.instruction: Use checkboxes format for rule-oriented acceptance criteria to enable clear pass/fail validation
instructions.original_snippets: ### Must Have - [ ] User can enter email and password - [ ] System validates email format - [ ] Login completes within 3 seconds
instructions.relevant_when: Writing rule-oriented acceptance criteria that need clear validation checkpoints

instructions.instruction: Write scenario names that describe user behavior, not system features
instructions.original_snippets: Good: 'User successfully logs in with valid credentials' Bad: 'Login endpoint returns 200'
instructions.relevant_when: Writing Given/When/Then scenarios for user-facing functionality

instructions.instruction: Keep Given statements to essential prerequisites that matter for the test, avoid irrelevant setup details
instructions.original_snippets: Given: Set up only the prerequisites that matter for this specific test scenario

instructions.instruction: Structure When statements as single, clear actions that trigger the behavior being tested
instructions.original_snippets: When: Describe the single action that triggers the behavior you're testing

instructions.instruction: Write Then statements that describe observable, measurable outcomes
instructions.original_snippets: Then: Focus on what the user can observe or measure

instructions.instruction: Include specific timing requirements using precise measurements (<=, >=, exact numbers)
instructions.original_snippets: Response time <= 500ms... Page loads in <= 2 seconds... Session timeout after 30 minutes of inactivity
instructions.relevant_when: Writing acceptance criteria for performance-sensitive features

instructions.instruction: Specify exact response codes and error handling for API-related acceptance criteria
instructions.original_snippets: Returns 201 Created status... Returns 400 Bad Request with validation errors... Returns 409 Conflict if email already exists
instructions.relevant_when: Writing acceptance criteria for API endpoints or backend services

instructions.instruction: Align with stakeholders before finalizing acceptance criteria to ensure shared understanding
instructions.original_snippets: Anti-Pattern: Bypassing stakeholder alignment... Validate with product owner, QA, and development team before implementation begins
instructions.relevant_when: Completing acceptance criteria for any user story before development begins
